Several news outlets have reported today that a number of Long Island school districts did not submit reopening plans to the state as required. Thank you for trusting that we can resolve this misunderstanding and move on with the important business of opening schools next month.

Tomorrow we will share a schedule of community and staff forums that will address school reopening.

Sincerely,

Kenneth E. Graham, Ed.D.
Superintendent of Schools

LVHS Named School of Excellence by New York State

Locust Valley High School has been named a School of Excellence by the New York State Public High Schools Athletic Association. Schools earning this distinction had more than 75 percent of their athletic teams earn scholar-athlete status during the 2019-2020 school year.

Scholar-athlete teams are those that attain an average GPA of 90 or above. Accomplishing such a feat requires a focused dedication to academics while spending hours on the field practicing and competing.

“We are extremely proud to have such a high percentage of athletic teams achieve on and off the fields,” said Locust Valley Central School District Director of Health, Physical Education and Athletics Dr. Danielle Turner. “Our student-athletes, coaches, teachers and parents work together to support such success.”

Locust Valley Intermediate School third grade teacher Shari Zindman has led her class to victory in the Walt Whitman Birthplace Association’s annual poetry contest for the 29th consecutive year.

Her class this year collaborated on a beautiful poetry anthology, earning them the title of Grand Champions in the grade 3-4 category of the Walt Whitman Birthplace Association’s 34th Annual Student Poetry Contest, “Leap Day.”

The theme centered around 2020 being a leap year and required students to write about an activity they would do given an extra day to do whatever they wanted.

Ms. Zindman used the poetry contest as an opportunity for her students to share their work with others and to learn that their writing is valued.

Congratulations to all of Ms. Zindman’s students on this incredible accomplishment!

Locust Valley Middle School and High School art students wanted to show their appreciation for all the work their teachers have done for them during remote learning by creating hearts out of materials they had in their homes.

Art teacher Donna Chaplin said the students are thankful and have gained valuable life skills while learning at home. “Our students learned flexible thinking when they saw their teachers trying to navigate and implement new methods to reach them and connect with them,” said Ms. Chaplin. She explained that the students learned by example that it is ok to fail and try again, as they watched their teachers learn new skills. “Our students are learning empathy and compassion by watching their teachers go above and beyond to help them continue to function as normally as possible while learning from a distance,” she said. “Most importantly, our students learned their teachers are essential and wanted to thank them from the bottom of their hearts.”

Classes are keeping up with the curriculum while learning at home.

Locust Valley Middle School teacher Lindsay McKinney found a way to take her class on exciting trips while stuck at home. They recently took two virtual field trips. The first adventure was to the Great Barrier Reef. Ms. McKinney created a simulation, including a flight on a plane and a boat ride, to emphasize the travel necessary to get to the location in Australia. Then, using Google Expedition, the students virtually explored the reef.

Next up, based on the students’ interest in Space X, the class watched live footage of activity at the International Space Station. This was a great way to make learning at home exciting! #ProudtobeLV

LVCSD Thanks Out Local Heroes

Bayville resident and LVHS alumna Amanda Kenny (’06) works for Northwell Health as a communication specialist/EMS dispatcher. In the communications office she works to ensure that crews and patients get to their destination in a timely and safe matter. She and her team take emergency 911 calls, organize transfers of patients from one hospital to another, communicate with the paramedics and EMTs on the ambulances to ensure they are safely routed to the proper places and dispatch ambulances to emergencies.

Amanda also volunteers for the Locust Valley Fire Department as an EMT and 1st Lieutenant for the Emergency Medical Rescue Co. She helps treat and transport sick and injured people in the Locust Valley community. Amanda is clearly doing an important job that has become even more important during the pandemic.

Thank you for being a hero in our community! #ProudtobeLV

Three Locust Valley High School seniors have been named National Merit Scholarship winners, receiving scholarships of $2,500 each. Nina Cialone, Michael DiSpirito and Michelle Hsu earned this incredible achievement.

The seniors are among 16,000 students chosen in the fall as semifinalists from 1.6 million high school juniors based on their 2019 PSAT scores. They were then among 15,000 high school students to advance to the finalist stage this spring after submitting detailed applications and an essay including information about their extracurricular activities, awards and leadership positions.

The National Merit Scholarship Corporation states that its sponsors join them to enhance the educational opportunities for America’s scholastically talented youth and to encourage the pursuit of excellence.

Congratulations to Nina, Michael and Michelle on this elite achievement!

National Library week continues with a guest post from AMP librarian Devon Gallagher and LVI librarian Anne Joyce.

Library media specialists in the elementary schools strive to foster a love of lifelong reading in children. With the unprecedented shutdown, librarians are promoting digital sources that provide recreational reading and research opportunities for all. SORA, the district’s digital library, offers students access to ebooks and audiobooks through the LVCSD elementary school collection, as well as access to Nassau County’s Digital Doorway. Library media specialists have worked together to develop a robust collection of titles to provide students with great books to read at home. They are also providing instruction on how to access the SORA library for virtual library checkout at any time! Check in with your library media specialist for help if you need.

Visit their eBoards or reach out to any of the LVCSD librarians to access digital resources.

In honor of National Library Week, LVCSD has a guest post from Bayville Primary School librarian Paige Coppola and Bayville Intermediate School librarian Stefanie Maura Lipsey. Here’s what they want to share:

We make library time a place where curiosity can safely flourish! Our young researchers are learning new ways to use the Internet. Common Sense Media (www.commonsensemedia.org) is an excellent resource that we share to help parents and students learn that everything you read on the Internet is not necessarily safe or accurate. Even Abraham Lincoln posted that on his Instagram account. Wait, no, of course he didn’t! But sometimes what is found on the internet is not fact and this is where librarians are key leaders in digital citizenship and training our youngest learners to be discerning users of information.

Librarians have always been leaders in literacy, research and technology and now, the world is really counting on them!

Ann MacArthur Primary School students in Ms. Kriesberg’s first grade class not only miss each other, they also miss their class mascot Rasheed. The stuffed lion is part of the Teachers College Phonics Workshop and serves as support for reading and writing lessons.

Ms. Kriesberg was surprised when during a small group Google Meet lesson, some of the students on the other side of her screen were holding Rasheed! They missed him so much, that they each got their own. Ms. Kriesberg said Rasheed is integral to engaging storylines such as the mystery of the silent "e" and being a word builder for Vowel Town, just to name a few of his jobs.

Rasheed dresses for each of his roles, wearing a detective suit when working as a word detective and a construction outfit for serving as a word builder among others. Rasheed was even included in a class photo this year.

Ms. Kriesberg said Rasheed helps reinforce reading and writing concepts. “The children love him and because of that connection, they take a more active role in learning the concepts he is reinforcing.”

Music Monday - It is not uncommon for music students to need assistance from their teachers when their instruments need tuning, adjusting or even repairing.

Locust Valley music teacher AnnMarie Buonaspina did not let the school closure stop her from helping when a string broke on her student's guitar. Eighth grader Ella could not get a new string in a timely manner due to the shipping delays caused by the coronavirus pandemic, so Ms. Buonaspina came to the rescue. She mailed Ella a string that she had in her house and once Ella received it, Ms. Buonaspina met with her through Google Meet to walk her through replacing the string.

Ella is now back to practicing for Ms. Buonaspina's eighth grade guitar class!

This is a wonderful example of the dedication we are seeing from Locust Valley teachers.

Locust Valley students may not be together, but they haven’t lost the Falcon spirit. The Locust Valley Elementary Parents’ Council organized a Virtual Spirit Week from March 23-27 for Ann MacArthur Primary School and Locust Valley Intermediate School students.

Each day, students were encouraged to dress up for that day’s theme and to do a specific activity. Children dressed in pajamas, wacky wardrobes, crazy hats and hair and sports team jerseys, leading up to the last spirit day which featured Falcon wear. Activities for each day included having breakfast with the family, reading in an unusual spot, doing chores around the house, getting outside and performing random acts of kindness.

LVEPC Co-President Meredith Wachter said spirit week was fun for everyone. “LVEPC Virtual Spirit Week was a way of staying connected, sharing in an activity while apart, and being able to see one another’s smiling faces, places and activities through the photos,” she said.

The State of a Root Beer Float

Root beer floats may sound appropriate for snack time, but in one second grade class, the delicious treats reinforced a unit of study on states of matter. Students in Amanda McCarthy’s class at Ann MacArthur Primary School were told they were doing an experiment using three states of matter. However, when each student was given only a small cup of ice cream and a small cup of root beer, they realized they only had two states of matter.

An apple a day may keep the doctor away, but for one student a McIntosh made her the Locust Valley Middle School spelling bee champion.

Spelling McIntosh correctly, seventh grader Inshaal Abid took the school title for the second year in a row. Last year, her winning word was “astonishment.” Both as a sixth grader and seventh grader she has beaten her older classmates to the podium.

Sixth grade runner-up Evie Bergman helped prove that age does not guarantee a win. The girls competed among 25 middle school students who had each been the winner in their individual English classes.

Inshaal now must take a 50-question written computer test to qualify for the Teachers Federal Credit Union Long Island Regional Spelling Bee on March 12, 2020. Each round of competition is part of the Scripps National Spelling Bee.

We are rooting for you, Inshaal!

Varsity and junior varsity volleyball players ditched their usual Falcon uniforms to wear pink during their annual Dig Pink fundraiser and nonleague game against Glen Cove High School.

The Falcons held a bake sale, with the proceeds going to the Dig Pink Side-Out Foundation. Dig Pink is a national breast cancer rally organized by the Side-Out Foundation, which encourages middle school and high school volleyball teams to hold events supporting the cause each October.

The pink-themed bake sale raised more than $500 for the cause, but just as importantly, raised awareness of an important topic. Varsity coach Bobbee Brancaccio said the event means a lot to the volleyball players. "They want to see fewer people diagnosed with cancer, and this is one way they can make a difference,” she said.

Reading Brings Community Together

Reading was a family affair for fourth graders at Locust Valley Intermediate School when their parents and guardians took time out of their busy days to come to school for a community read-a-long.

Sitting on blankets under trees or in the warmth of the sun, students and their families read a variety of books. District administrators and teachers read to students whose families could not attend.

Fourth grade teachers organized the event to help highlight to students not only the importance of reading, but also that reading can be a wonderful way to bring people together.

ENL Orientation Welcomes Parents

Parents of English language learners came together for an orientation session to learn about school processes and procedures, various services their children will receive and who to call when they have questions.

Amy Watson, coordinator for ENL and world languages, K-12, ran the orientation with the help of teaching assistant Cynthia Ergen. The parents not only absorbed the information shared, but had the opportunity to ask all the questions they had.

“Bilingual children have unique qualities that we want to help them develop,” Ms. Watson said. “The best way to do so is to work in partnership with the students and their families.”

Some of the topics covered included how to access the parent portal and eBoard, as well as how the ENL program operates and the individual services students receive based on their English-speaking skills.

While this orientation was for families just entering the district, there will be other events held for all ENL families, including Bilingual Night on Oct. 17 and 24.

Announcement from the LVCSD Board of Education

Dr. Anna F. Hunderfund, Superintendent of the Locust Valley School District, has announced her retirement effective June 30, 2020. Dr. Hunderfund began her tenure in Locust Valley in 2008 and has served the District as Superintendent of Schools for the past 12 years. Under her leadership, Locust Valley Central School District schools have been recognized as being among the best on Long Island, in New York State and in the country.
The Locust Valley Board of Education would like to express its sincere gratitude to Dr. Hunderfund for her many years of service to the District. Her hard work and dedication to the success of all children have helped to make Locust Valley an exemplary district of which we are very proud.
